issues.text: Whether Article 133 of the Hyderabad Limitation Act continued to apply by reason of proviso to Section 6 Part-B States Laws Act 1951

anchor.surface_text: By art. 133 of the Hyderabad Limitation Act, the period of limitation for a suit by a mortgagee for foreclosure was thirty years from the date when the money secured by the mortgage became due. But as from April 1, 1951, the Hyderabad Limitation Act was repealed and the Indian Limitation Act, 1908 was extended to the State of Hyderabad by the Part-B States Laws Act Act III of 1951

holdings.text: That sub-rule [Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule 1 CPC], however, cannot justify the order, for it only permits addition of a plaintiff and does number provide for the addition of a defendant while the order directs addition of both a plaintiff and two defendants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual application of sub-rule 1 which authorizes only plaintiff addition, not defendants.

holdings.text: The addition of Mahabalkumari as a plaintiff could number be made under the sub-rule unless it was necessary for the determination of the real matter in dispute.

Now, adding her as a plaintiff would have availed numberhing unless Rajkumari and Premkumari were also added as defendants, and that companyld number be done under the sub-rule.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Addition futile without adding sisters as defendants, which sub-rule 1 does not allow; not necessary for real dispute.

holdings.text: In view of s. 22 of the Limitation Act, the suit as regards the parties added under [Order 1 Rule 10 sub-rule 2] had to be deemed to have been instituted when they were added.

anchor.surface_text: Now, sub-r. 2 of 0. 1, r. 10 permits the addition of both plaintiffs and defendants in certain circumstances. The order however was number sought to be justified under that provision and there was good reason for it. holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory deeming provision of S.22 applies to additions under sub-rule 2, rendering suit time-barred.

holdings.text: Section 22 makes number distinction between sub-r. 1 and sub-r. 2 of 0. 1, r. 10. The section in express terms applies whenever a new plaintiff or a new defendant is substituted after the institution of a suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of S.22 applies uniformly regardless of which sub-rule used for addition.

holdings.text: A suit by a person claiming to be the sole owner of the properties of a business carried on in a firm name... is number a suit in a representative capacity.

First, a suit by a person claiming to be the sole owner of the properties of a business carried on in a firm name, as Vijay Kumars suit was, is number a suit in a representative capacity he represents numberone but himself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Firm not legal entity; sole claimant suit not representative; added parties have antagonistic claims.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No vested right under repealed Act; Indian Limitation Act applies post-extension; S.30 safeguards where applicable.

holdings.text: Art. 147 applied only to an English mortgage as defined in the Transfer of Property Act before its amendment in 1929... The present suit was for foreclosure only, and was governed by art. 132 and number art. 147.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the respondents that art. 147 of the Indian Limitation Act applied to the suit. ... In Vasudeva Mudaliar v. S. Shriniwas Pillai, 1  the Privy Council held that Art. 147 applied only to an English mortgage... The deed dated December 13, 1934 created an anomalous mortgage... The present suit was for foreclosure only, and was governed by art. 132 and number art. 147.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent (Privy Council) limits Art.147 to English mortgages allowing sale; anomalous mortgage foreclosure only under Art.132.

holdings.text: The deed dated December 13, 1934 created an anomalous mortgage and companyferred a right of foreclosure only upon the mortgagee. The mortgagee had number right to sue for sale in the alternative.

anchor.surface_text: The deed dated December 13, 1934 created an anomalous mortgage and companyferred a right of foreclosure only upon the mortgagee. The mortgagee had numberright to sue for sale in the alternative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Deed terms confer foreclosure only, fitting anomalous mortgage definition.

holdings.text: The main question... whether the claim of Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari to enforce the mortgage is barred by limitation... As far as they are companycerned, the suit is barred by limitation and number decree can be passed in their favour.

anchor.surface_text: The main question in this appeal is whether the claim of Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari to enforce the mortgage is barred by limitation. ... It follows that as regards Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari the suit must be regarded as instituted on November 4, 1958. As far as they are companycerned, the suit is barred by limitation and numberdecree can be passed in their favour.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.22 deems suit instituted on addition date (Nov 4, 1958); beyond 12-year limit from due date under Art.132.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural power exists under CPC rules, but limitation prevents relief.

precedents.citation: Vasudeva Mudaliar v. S. Shriniwas Pillai, 1

anchor.surface_text: In Vasudeva Mudaliar v. S. Shriniwas Pillai, 1 the Privy Council held that Art. 147 applied only to an English mortgage as defined in the Transfer of Property Act before its amendment in 1929

precedents.case_name: Vasudeva Mudaliar v S Shriniwas Pillai
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 147 applies only to English mortgage where mortgagee can sue for foreclosure or sale
precedents.cited_holding: Art. 147 applied only to an English mortgage as defined in the Transfer of Property Act before its amendment in 1929

anchor.surface_text: In Moyappa Chetty v. Supramanian Chetty 2 , the Privy Council had occasion to consider the similar provisions of s. 22 of the Straits Settlements Ordinance No. 6 of 1896

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 22 contemplates cases where suit is defective because the person in whom right of suit vests is not before the court

precedents.citation: Subodini Devi v. Cumar Ganoda Kant Roy, Bahadur 1

anchor.surface_text: In Subodini Devi v. Cumar Ganoda Kant Roy, Bahadur 1 , the Calcutta High Court held that there was a difference between substituting a new person as plaintiff under s. 27 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1882 and the addition of a new person as defendant under s. 32 of the Code

precedents.case_name: Subodini Devi v Cumar Ganoda Kant Roy Bahadur
precedents.cited_proposition: change of parties as plaintiffs did not affect limitation; difference between substitution of plaintiff and addition of defendant

anchor.surface_text: The High Court purported to make the order under sub-r. 1 of 0. 1, r. 10 of the Code of Civil Procedure. We were number called upon by companynsel to companysider any other provision. That sub-rule, however, cannot justify the order, for it only permits addition of a plaintiff and does number provide for the addition of a defendant while the order directs addition of both a plaintiff and two defendants.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondents Nos. 2,3 and 4, Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari, is set aside and the decree of the trial Court dismissing the suit is restored. The suit is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The main question in this appeal is whether the claim of Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari to enforce the mortgage is barred by limitation. ... It follows that as regards Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari the suit must be regarded as instituted on November 4, 1958. As far as they are companycerned, the suit is barred by limitation and numberdecree can be passed in their favour.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondents Nos. 2,3 and 4, Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari, is set aside and the decree of the trial Court dismissing the suit is restored. The suit is dismissed.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondents Nos. 2,3 and 4, Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari, is set aside and the decree of the trial Court dismissing the suit is restored. The suit is dismissed.

Was it then properly made in solar as it added a plaintiff ? I do number think so. The addition of Mahabalkumari as a plaintiff companyld number be made under the sub-rule unless it was necessary for the determination of the real matter in dispute. Now, adding her as a plaintiff would have availed numberhing unless Rajkumari and Premkumari were also added as defendants, and that companyld number be done under the sub-rule.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondents Nos. 2,3 and 4, Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari, is set aside and the decree of the trial Court dismissing the suit is restored. The suit is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Now, sub-r. 2 of 0. 1, r. 10 permits the addition of both plaintiffs and defendants in certain circumstances. The order however was number sought to be justified under that provision and there was good reason for it. It was companyceded-and in my opinion rightly-that in view of s. 22 of the Limitation Act. the suit as regards the parties added under this sub-rule had to be deemed to have been instituted when they were added.

In the result, the appeal is allowed, the decree passed by the High Court in favour of respondents Nos. 2,3 and 4, Mahabalkumari, Rajkumari and Premkumari, is set aside and the decree of the trial Court dismissing the suit is restored. The suit is dismissed.
